nodes.text: Partial modelling using Boolean networks and related techniques can help address the malaise in neoclassical economics by serving as inductive, exploratory cognitive instruments
Wallace proposes deploying partial modelling with Boolean networks (BNs) as an inductive discovery procedure to develop economic theory and suggests combining partial models into larger models
Boolean networks have been applied in fields such as systems biology and are often described as having high predictive power in that context
Orrell agrees that models should be treated as cognitive instruments and partial approximations and that economics can learn from the diversity of modelling approaches used in systems biology

Orrell argues that the proposed BN-based strategy and the automatic joining/extending of partial models face structural and predictive limitations that undermine the goal of building larger comprehensive models
Orrell recommends an alternative dashboard approach: keep a range of different model types mostly separate, limit model size, and complement models rather than automatically combining them
The BN-combination method relies on simplification procedures such as excluding node values that produce multiple steady states and omitting feedback loops to avoid oscillations
The BN strategy asserts BNs can include qualitative components with minimal quantitative data and can be converted into continuous dynamical systems (ODEs)
In practice in systems biology the term 'predict' is often used to mean reproducing known or non-surprising results or calibration rather than true blind prediction

Pruning features such as feedback loops or multistability can remove essential structure, and combining patches does not guarantee improved models because model structure, not size, may be the limiting factor

Adding nodes or converting to ODEs does not necessarily capture dynamics that require different model structures (e.g., stochastic effects, agent interactions, or nonclassical probability), so extension may fail to address underlying problems

Examples show structure matters: yeast gene regulation produced experimentally important stochastic effects invisible to any ODE model; drug companies use ODE/agent-based hybrids to capture population dynamics; quantum decision theory requires nonclassical probability; monetary systems resist naive insertion into DSGE models
Simple models often give better predictive results than very large models, but they do not provide a complete picture
Complex living systems suffer from 'sloppy parameters' where adding model detail increases unknown parameters and structural uncertainty, making parameters undeterminable from data
Orrell's dashboard approach treats each model as complementary, limits model size to avoid high-dimensionality problems, and integrates insights without forcing structural unification
Before combining models, investigators should examine incentives and funding sources because external incentives can shape assumptions and research questions and bias modelling approaches
